title: Measuring Length with Informal Units
description: Measure length using paperclips, hand spans, and other informal units
objectives: Measure length using informal units like paperclips and hand spans
Understand that you must place units end-to-end with no gaps or overlaps
Compare lengths measured in the same informal unit

sections.title: Measuring Without a Ruler!
sections.content:
In Foundation, you learned to compare objects by length -- which is longer and which is shorter. Now it is time to **measure** how long things are!

But we won't use a ruler just yet. Instead, we will use everyday objects like **paperclips**, **hand spans**, and **blocks** to measure. These are called **informal units**.

sections.title: How to Measure with Informal Units
sections.content:
**Informal units** are everyday objects we use to measure.

**Common informal units:**
- **Paperclips** -- line them up along the object
- **Hand spans** -- spread your hand and measure fingertip to fingertip
- **Blocks** or **cubes** -- place them in a line
- **Footsteps** -- walk heel-to-toe

**Rules for measuring:**
1. Start at one end of the object
2. Place units **end-to-end** (touching, with no gaps)
3. Do **not overlap** units
4. Count how many units fit along the object

The number of units tells you the **length**.

For example: "My pencil is **6 paperclips** long."

sections.title: Example: Measuring a Book with Paperclips
sections.content:
How long is a book? Let's measure with paperclips.

1. Put the first paperclip at one end of the book.
2. Place the next paperclip right next to it -- no gaps!
3. Keep going until you reach the other end of the book.
4. Count the paperclips: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8

The book is **8 paperclips** long.

Remember: no gaps and no overlaps. If there are gaps, the measurement will be too big. If there are overlaps, it will be too small.

sections.title: Example: Comparing Lengths
sections.content:
Sam measures his desk with hand spans. It is **5 hand spans** long.
Emma measures her desk with hand spans. It is **4 hand spans** long.

Whose desk is longer?

1. Sam's desk: 5 hand spans
2. Emma's desk: 4 hand spans
3. 5 is more than 4
4. So Sam's desk is **longer**.

Important: We can only compare when we use the **same unit**. It would not be fair to compare 5 hand spans with 8 paperclips!

sections.title: Same Unit, Fair Comparison
sections.content:
To compare measurements fairly, you must use the **same informal unit**.

If one person measures a table with paperclips and another measures with blocks, you cannot easily compare the numbers because the units are different sizes.

Also, different people have different-sized hands, so hand span measurements might be slightly different from person to person!

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
Great job! In this lesson you learned:

- **Informal units** are everyday objects used for measuring (paperclips, hand spans, blocks)
- Place units **end-to-end** with no gaps and no overlaps
- **Count** the units to find the length
- Use the **same unit** to compare lengths fairly

Try measuring things in your classroom with paperclips or blocks!

workedExamples.title: Measuring with Paperclips
workedExamples.problem: A pencil case fits exactly 10 paperclips along its length. A ruler fits 6 paperclips. Which is longer?
steps: The pencil case is 10 paperclips long.
The ruler is 6 paperclips long.
Both are measured in the same unit (paperclips), so we can compare.
10 is more than 6, so the pencil case is longer.
workedExamples.solution: The **pencil case** is longer (10 paperclips vs 6 paperclips).
workedExamples.explanation: Since both objects were measured with the same unit (paperclips), we can compare the numbers directly. 10 is greater than 6, so the pencil case is longer.

workedExamples.title: Measuring with Hand Spans
workedExamples.problem: A table is 8 hand spans long. A bench is 12 hand spans long. How many more hand spans is the bench?
steps: Table = 8 hand spans, Bench = 12 hand spans.
Both measured in hand spans, so we can compare.
Find the difference: 12 - 8 = 4.
The bench is 4 hand spans longer.
workedExamples.solution: The bench is **4 hand spans** longer than the table.
workedExamples.explanation: We subtract to find the difference: 12 - 8 = 4. The bench is 4 hand spans longer than the table.

title: Telling Time: O'Clock and Half Past
description: Read and write times to the hour and half hour on a clock
objectives: Read o'clock times on a clock face
Read half-past times on a clock face
Connect clock times to daily activities

sections.title: What Time Is It?
sections.content:
Clocks help us know what time it is. Knowing the time helps us get to school, eat lunch, and go to bed at the right time!

A clock has two hands:
- The **short hand** (hour hand) points to the **hour**
- The **long hand** (minute hand) tells us the **minutes**

Today we will learn to read two important times: **o'clock** and **half past**.

sections.title: O'Clock Times
sections.content:
When the **long hand** (minute hand) points straight up to the **12**, it is an **o'clock** time.

The **short hand** (hour hand) tells us which hour it is.

**Examples:**
- Short hand on 3, long hand on 12 = **3 o'clock**
- Short hand on 7, long hand on 12 = **7 o'clock**
- Short hand on 12, long hand on 12 = **12 o'clock**

**Remember:** For o'clock times, the long hand always points to **12**.

sections.title: Half Past Times
sections.content:
When the **long hand** points straight down to the **6**, it is a **half past** time. This means half an hour has passed since the last o'clock.

The **short hand** will be **between** two numbers.

**Examples:**
- Short hand between 3 and 4, long hand on 6 = **half past 3**
- Short hand between 8 and 9, long hand on 6 = **half past 8**

**Remember:** For half past times, the long hand always points to **6**.

sections.title: Example: Reading O'Clock
sections.content:
The long hand points to 12. The short hand points to 5.

What time is it?

1. The long hand is on 12 -- so it is an **o'clock** time.
2. The short hand is on 5 -- so the hour is **5**.
3. Put them together: **5 o'clock**.

It is **5 o'clock**. This might be time for afternoon tea!

sections.title: Example: Reading Half Past
sections.content:
The long hand points to 6. The short hand is between 9 and 10.

What time is it?

1. The long hand is on 6 -- so it is a **half past** time.
2. The short hand has passed 9 but has not reached 10 yet.
3. So the hour is still **9**.
4. Put them together: **half past 9**.

It is **half past 9**. This might be time for morning tea at school!

sections.title: The Two Hands
sections.content:
Always look at **both hands** on the clock:

| Long hand points to | It is... |
|---|---|
| **12** (top) | ... o'clock |
| **6** (bottom) | half past ... |

The **short hand** tells you the hour number.

A common mistake is mixing up the two hands. Remember: the **short** hand is for the **hour** and the **long** hand is for the **minutes**.

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
Well done! In this lesson you learned:

- A clock has a **short hand** (hour) and a **long hand** (minutes)
- When the long hand points to **12**, it is **o'clock**
- When the long hand points to **6**, it is **half past**
- The short hand tells us **which hour**

Practise reading the clock at home. What time do you eat dinner? What time do you go to bed?

workedExamples.title: Reading an O'Clock Time
workedExamples.problem: The short hand points to 8 and the long hand points to 12. What time is it?
steps: The long hand is on 12, so it is an o'clock time.
The short hand is on 8, so the hour is 8.
Put them together: 8 o'clock.
workedExamples.explanation: When the long hand points to 12, it is an o'clock time. The short hand on 8 tells us the hour. So it is 8 o'clock -- maybe time for school!

workedExamples.title: Reading a Half Past Time
workedExamples.problem: The short hand is between 1 and 2. The long hand points to 6. What time is it?
steps: The long hand is on 6, so it is a half past time.
The short hand has passed 1 but not reached 2.
So the hour is 1.
Put them together: half past 1.
workedExamples.explanation: The long hand on 6 tells us it is half past. The short hand has gone past 1, so the hour is 1. It is half past 1 -- maybe time for lunch!

title: Comparing and Ordering Mass
description: Compare mass using balance scales and order objects by mass
objectives: Use a balance scale to compare the mass of two objects
Order three or more objects from lightest to heaviest
Understand that balance means equal mass

sections.title: Which Is Heavier? Using Balance Scales
sections.content:
In Foundation, you learned to heft objects in your hands to see which is heavier. Now we will use a special tool called a **balance scale** to compare mass more accurately.

A balance scale has two sides. When you put objects on each side, the heavier side goes **down** and the lighter side goes **up**. If both sides are level, the objects have the **same mass**.

sections.title: How a Balance Scale Works
sections.content:
A balance scale helps us compare mass:

- **One side goes down** -- that side is heavier
- **One side goes up** -- that side is lighter
- **Both sides are level** -- both sides have the same mass (they balance)

**To compare two objects:**
1. Put one object on the left side
2. Put the other object on the right side
3. See which side goes down

**To order three objects:**
1. Compare the first two objects
2. Compare the heavier one with the third object
3. Put them in order from lightest to heaviest

sections.title: Example: Comparing Two Objects
sections.content:
A banana is placed on the left side of a balance scale. An orange is placed on the right side. The right side goes down.

Which is heavier?

1. The right side (with the orange) goes down.
2. The side that goes down has the heavier object.
3. So the **orange** is heavier than the banana.
4. The **banana** is lighter than the orange.

sections.title: Example: Ordering Three Objects
sections.content:
We want to order a book, a pencil, and a lunch box from lightest to heaviest.

**Step 1:** Compare the book and the pencil. The book is heavier.
**Step 2:** Compare the book and the lunch box. The lunch box is heavier.
**Step 3:** Compare the pencil and the lunch box. The lunch box is heavier.

So: pencil is lightest, book is in the middle, lunch box is heaviest.

**From lightest to heaviest:** pencil, book, lunch box.

sections.title: Balancing Means Equal
sections.content:
When a balance scale is perfectly **level** (both sides are the same height), the objects on each side have **equal mass**.

If you put 5 blocks on one side and the object balances with those 5 blocks, then the object has the same mass as 5 blocks.

This is like using blocks as an informal unit to measure mass -- just like we used paperclips to measure length!

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
Terrific! In this lesson you learned:

- A **balance scale** compares the mass of objects
- The **heavier side goes down**, the **lighter side goes up**
- When both sides are **level**, the objects have **equal mass**
- You can **order** objects from lightest to heaviest by comparing pairs

Try using a balance scale to compare objects in your classroom!

workedExamples.title: Using a Balance Scale
workedExamples.problem: A toy car is on the left side of a balance scale. A toy train is on the right side. The left side goes down. Which toy is lighter?
steps: The left side (toy car) goes down, so the toy car is heavier.
If the toy car is heavier, the toy train must be lighter.
The toy train is lighter.
workedExamples.explanation: On a balance scale, the side that goes down is heavier. Since the toy car's side went down, the toy car is heavier and the toy train is lighter.

workedExamples.title: Ordering by Mass
workedExamples.problem: A marble is lighter than a rubber. A rubber is lighter than a stapler. Put them in order from heaviest to lightest.
steps: The marble is lighter than the rubber.
The rubber is lighter than the stapler.
So: marble is lightest, rubber is in the middle, stapler is heaviest.
From heaviest to lightest: stapler, rubber, marble.
workedExamples.solution: From heaviest to lightest: **stapler, rubber, marble**.
workedExamples.explanation: The stapler is heavier than the rubber, and the rubber is heavier than the marble. So the order from heaviest to lightest is: stapler, rubber, marble.
